posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked:
Lots of older posts from a few years ago on non-Omio CNC routers. Not a lot of new stuff.

Background: we‚Äôre going to be new to CNC. A sponsor has made a donation for my team to buy a CNC router. The mentor from this sponsor likes (and so do we!) the Axiom Pro AR8 . We were hoping to buy it back in December, but school progress on connecting 240v to our work space was slow. Now things are aligning and we want to make the purchase.*

CAD: we use Onshape

Axiom sells two software packages ( Aspire v11x , vCarve pro ), and I don‚Äôt know which would be best for standard FRC manufacturing. Or, if there is something else the community recommends. Maybe something cheaper!

Our usage: likely doing a lot of polycarb parts out of 1/8 or 1/4 sheets, also parts from similar thickness aluminum, and cutting pockets or holes in rectangular tubing. I‚Äôm sure we‚Äôll experiment with a lot more, but for now we want to be able to start making replacement parts for our current robot in time for a week 4 regional‚Ä¶ you know, just incase things break at our week 2.

All suggestions welcome!

*I was told by an Axiom rep that in March they will be offering the router table free with purchase of the router. So we‚Äôre waiting until then.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked:
I haven‚Äôt worked with V carve or Aspire unfortunately, but I can say that Fusion 360 has a great CAM package that works well for FRC. I even have templates and tool libraries available. My workflow is downloading CAD from Onshape, import to fusion, arrange parts on sheet, apply CAM, generate G code. The flow is probably similar for the router CAMs you‚Äôre looking at. Generally, router-specofic CAM programs have better tools for working with sheet metal, but lack finesse or the ability to tweak things. Easier to use, less flexible.

The router you‚Äôre looking at looks similar to an Omio in terms of capabilities, so it should be good. That said, bang for the buck, the Omio still reigns supreme. It does have more bugs than the Axiom is likely to have.

For tooling, Thriftybot and WCP have great endmills. You can also get a pack of 30 from Grewin in China for about $140 shipped, for a combo of 4mm and 6mm endmills. This is the old Ozzyboards supplier. You need a quote and stuff to buy from them so it‚Äôs a little inconvenient.

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
We‚Äôve been happy enough with Vectric cut2d pro. It‚Äôs plenty functional and very cheap.

I do miss the deep control of HSMworks CAM, which is the same package that‚Äôs integrated to Autodesk F360.

The F360 package is hard to run on Chromebook quality laptops (slow processors no ram no graphics even with windows) and has too many dials for us to teach inexperienced students easily‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm hoping to get back on it next year when we figure out updated laptops, and think it‚Äôs a good option in general.

posts.name: Jon K.
posts.cooked: You can get Mastercam free through the virtual kit of parts! Can‚Äôt be free, especially when it‚Äôs one of the best CAM software programs out there.

posts.name: Andrew Nabors
posts.cooked: We use Vcarve pro with our shop Sabre and have found it really easy to use and work with. The learning curve is very minimal and have been able to train students quickly on it to keep our machine running.

posts.name: Anshul Bajaj
posts.cooked:
Zook:

( Aspire v11x , vCarve pro )

Aspire & vCarve Pro are by far the two most common ‚ÄúCAM‚Äù packages sold/provided alongside CNC routers. I have used both, and I have the free vcarve license that came with my shopsabre. Both work alright, but aren‚Äôt the best for FRC (and the prices Vectric charges are unreasonable). They are really best suited for woodshop use. 99.9% of the CAM work (both mill & router) I do happens in Fusion 360, which is both free (for education) and significantly more powerful. I occasionally pull out Vcarve pro for some ‚Äúartsy‚Äù wood projects, but that is about it.

For your use case, I would strongly recommend Fusion. It is an actual 3D CAM platform and the tools allow for much more precise control of cut settings and toolpaths. Aside from just being more capable, it‚Äôs a better program for students to learn, with industry-level concepts and techniques. I would just make sure that Axiom has a Fusion 360 post-processor.

posts.name: Dan Nichols
posts.cooked: If you use SOLIDWORKS then HSMWorks is, I‚Äôd say, the best integrated package, and it‚Äôs free for FRC teams. I‚Äôve tried SOLIDWORKS CAM but it is just sorta too complicated. If you‚Äôre just making simple 2.5D parts then you can get a pretty simple workflow where your make a few operation templates you copy into each part. Some of the ‚Äúbetter‚Äù tools like MasterCAM seem good for making really fancy, optimized toolpaths but not for just getting things done. Sorta like SOLIDWORKS vs CATIA. We ended up getting a license for vCarve but never used it. Might be better for, y‚Äôknow, v-carving and tabbing parts but we don‚Äôt do it that way and exporting to an external tool is a pain.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 548 Robostangs Electrical & Pneumatics Lead Mentor

posts.custom_user_title: FRC 548 Robostangs Electrical & Pneumatics Lead Mentor

posts.name: Jon K.
posts.cooked: I disagree with this though about Mastercam being for ‚Äúnot getting things done.‚Äù You can do that same workflow kind of thing in Mastercam using transforms, or, if you want sheet optimization you have access to nesting as part of their software. There were so many times when I just needed a one off part, and I was able to get it done in about 3-4 minutes of CAM time at most. You can get really fancy in Mastercam, or do some really quick and dirty toolpaths. It‚Äôs up to you,a nd what you‚Äôre trying to do. There (was, I think they obsoleted it finally) an integrated Mastercam for Solidworks add on as well, that you may still be able to get access to.

posts.name: Cory
posts.cooked:
Jon_K:

There (was, I think they obsoleted it finally) an integrated Mastercam for Solidworks add on as well, that you may still be able to get access to.

Nope, it is very much alive and well. Would strongly recommend FRC teams use this over standalone mastercam (unless you don‚Äôt use SW).

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked:
With Mastercam and F360 being free for education/FRC, I think we‚Äôll take a look at those first.

Thank you for all the input!

We use an autoroute 6 pro+ and it‚Äôs pretty good! I tried out fusion 360 can at the beginning of the season since that is what we are using for cad and I have to admit it‚Äôs a bit clunky, and less efficient. Vcarve is what we use for the majority of our cam and it‚Äôs pretty simple, easy to import vectors from drawing files, easy to create new designs, and really nice interface for choosing feed and speeds and such. I was a complete beginner to cam and picked the whole program up within an hour, it‚Äôs intuitive to learn which is a definite benefit because that way you can easily teach multiple people on your team to use it.

I have mostly used it to cut poly, which it‚Äôs worked out well for, being able to easily configure pass depth, tabs, etc. I‚Äôve also used it to cut brackets. One caveat I should add is I‚Äôve only done 2d vector machining so far, so keep that in mind.
Also, I don‚Äôt know your team‚Äôs situation but we get vcarve free from our school.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: Mastercam is fairly difficult to use, so be sure to get someone to show you how to set it up. F360 it‚Äôs much more approachable.
